title: Hey, for the 1,626th time: Flat Armor Pen is not good vs Tanks
body: There's literally no discussion or debate here. It's simply not good, the armor pen values don't stack up nearly as quickly as a tank can stack up armor values.

replies.body:
I'm so tired of this damn tank circle jerk. Tanks aren't bad, tanks aren't melting any faster than they've normally melted. Every tank is maintaining a 50%+ winrate right now and tanks still get picked frequently in bot, jungle and top in competitive. And to top it off, this absolutely awful circle jerk is spreading this ridiculous notion that flat armor pen is the reason tanks are weak when everyone fucking knows flat pen is bad against tanks. 

It needs to stop and it needs to stop now.

Actually, flat armor pen is a problem for people to 100 armor, at least.
This a nice value where you'd start to take considerably less damage from AD targets and feel like you're getting tankier in the process but earlier flat armor pen in builds pretty much negate a portion of that armor and you feel like you haven't bought much armor at all.

Ever since the Korean builds for certain ADCs took over, the rune pages have changed.
Earlier it was all about AS quints + AD marks and now it's AD quints and armor pen marks.

#That's:

Battering Blows = 7% armor pen (Ferocity tree Mastery)
Marks 0.91 x 9 = 8.20 flat armor pen 
Youmuu's = 20 flat armor pen _**(3200 g)**_
Serrated Dirk = 10 flat armor pen (builds into Maw or Duskblade) _**(1100g)**_

#Here's how it works on a 100 armor target (50 base + 50 bonus)

1. Battering Blows = 96.55 armor (48.83 base + 47.72 bonus)
2. Total pen = 38.2 flat armor pen _**(4300g value)**_
**Total armor value = 58.35 armor**
_**Total loss = - 41.65 armor**_


#Here's how it works on a 150 armor target (50 base + 100 bonus)

1. Battering Blows = 144.27 armor (48.83 base + 95.44 bonus)
2. Total pen = 38.2 flat armor pen _**(4300g value)**_
**Total armor value = 106.7 armor**
_**Total loss = - 43.3 armor**_
---
#Here's how it works on a 100 armor target (50 base + 50 bonus)
#Lord Dominik's equation

1. Battering Blows = 96.55 armor (48.83 base + 47.72 bonus)
2. Total pen = 8.20 flat armor pen _**(9 Marks)**_
3. Dominik's = 75.07 armor (48.83 base + 26.25 bonus) _**(2700g)**_
**Total armor value = 66.87 armor**
_**Total loss = - 33.12 armor**_

#Here's how it works on a 150 armor target (50 base + 100 bonus)
#Lord Dominik's equation

1. Battering Blows = 144.27 armor (48.83 base + 95.44 bonus)
2. Total pen = 8.20 flat armor pen _**(9 Marks)**_
3. Dominik's = 101.32 armor (48.83 base + 52.49 bonus) _**(2700g)**_
**Total armor value = 93.12 armor**
_**Total loss = - 56.88 armor**_
---

As you can see from these equations, Battering Blows goes through more armor with more armor on hand as it is a percentage based reduction. One thing you can see is that in the first 2 flat armor equations, the armor loss is more or less the same while in the last 2 equations (Lord Dominik ones), the more bonus armor you have, the greater the armor loss it is.

There's also a difference in prices in these "builds": _**2700g VS 4300g (1600 gold difference)**_
Does that mean Lord Dominik's route is better? it does not actually.
The difference here is that more combat stats and flat armor pen is great for dealing with semi-tanks and squishies alike as opposed to Lord Dominik's tank killing properties and less combat stats. It's all relative now.
Targets with close to 100 armor (early tanks) become the squishies with a bit more HP to burn through but not with enough damage to kill you while squishies become even more squishier to you.

Flat armor is great for Mages with a Zhonya's as they fall into close to 100 armor category. They're unlikely to stack any more armor than that. For the time being, you're not making a mistake going with a flat armor build even if it costs you a bit extra gold as it is great at dealing with people early-mid game and you can always purchase a Lord Dominik's or Mortal Reminder if tanks bother you.

i've just taken into account {{item:3142}} and {{item:3134}}. More flat armor from {{item:3147}} and {{item:3156}} is even better as tanks unlikely reach full tank status in the time the ADC with this build starts going nuts on kills.

---

##Keep in mind that this is mathematical proof that flat armor is not a bad build to go with these days. I'm not making an argument that this build destroys full tanks as it does not. Last Whisper line of items are real tank killing items and flat armor pen can't even compare to a target with close 300 armor god stats. However, this builds makes wannabe tanks' jobs harder if they're constantly getting bullied and killed before they're able to get gold for their items to bully the ADCs.

I didn't say flat armor pen builds were bad, I said flat armor pen builds are not good for killing tanks. And no, by the time an ADC has completed two flat pen items, a tank will easily have completed two armor items, like randuins and deadmans as an example. And those two armor pen items offer very little DPS, which is why only a few ADCs can build it and typically assassins are better with this build.

In short, in order to deal with tanks, percentage armor pen is required. Period. This means flat pen alone is not going to kill tanks.

>And no, by the time an ADC has completed two flat pen items, a tank will easily have completed two armor items, like randuins and deadmans as an example.

Most tanks can't rush Rands>Deadmans. They have to build either Cinderhulk to jungle or a specific item to cope in lane, which in some cases is Sunfire (which would be OK in this case) but often isn't. For example Maokai and Singed often rush RoA.
You aren't a real tank if you don't have 150 armor by the time adc has 4300 gold worth of items.
toplane maoki building roa into sunfire isn't a real tank?  And what if the top lane tank is against an ap champ and needs to build a magic-resist item first?

You drop the 1200 on Spectre and go on with your life. You shouldn't need much more than that if there is only 1-2 AP "threats" to deal with, for the early game at least (and even then a BV+Rot will provide more than enough MR come late game).

RoA into Sunfire would be an AP bruiser build. So that would be tank building bruiser, while I was mainly referring to the fact people think building a couple defensive items makes them a tank. Lvl 11 Mao with spectres cowl and frozen heart (4300g) has 163 armor plus 20% dmg reduction and the AS slow.

I don't really understand the context of some of your terms here (exponential formula for ANYTHING in league, also 'elasticity' used in a non-economics sense).  So, feel free to correct me if I'm speaking to something else below:

**1)  Armor and MR don't have diminishing returns.**  EHP scales linearly with armor, such that each point of armor adds 1% of your HP to your EHP.  The first point of armor adds the same amount to your EHP as the 100th point does.  The diminishing returns myth comes about because players look at damage reduction, which is the inverse of EHP and therefore doesn't scale linearly with defense (and thank god it doesn't as the difference between 100% damage reduction and 99% is immortality while 10% from 9% is a modest ~1% increase in EHP).  

**2)  This point of yours seems to be taking a good many liberties.**  When does Shyvana have 1235 health?  Level 9?  I can look at level 1 instead and show ruby crystal outperforms long sword in percent increase to their respective stats, per gold spent.  

Even beyond that, how do you compare different stats' utility/value?  Are you creating a metric like EHP*DPS?  Do tanks based on disruption benefit from DPS as much as GP does?  Same question for carries and EHP relative to those tanks.   

**3)  Lastly, does your treatment have an explanation for those metas where tanks have been dominant?**  Based on stat costs and considerations of %increase/gold spent, I don't see any room for other context.  

PS)  You can only take someone to negative armor/MR through amassing enough reduction to do it alone.  Penetration will never take someone below zero, nor will reduction on top of penetration.  Not sure if you were just using negative values for an extension to allow you to motivate the use of an exponential, but those values are almost never going to happen.

[Even on a linear (straight) demand or supply curve, the elasticity is not constant for the whole curve. The reason for this is that we are measuring the percentage change in both price and quantity. As you move along a linear curve and approach one of the axes, the percentage changes in that axis variable (either price or quantity) get smaller and smaller and the percentage changes of the opposite axis get bigger and bigger.](http://economics.fundamentalfinance.com/micro_price-elasticity.php)

Are you considering some combined metric of EHP*DPS such that you can argue the faster stat doubling for attack makes it the more attractive stat?  Wouldn't this treatment also make crit-scaling look superior to all other scalings?  How well does that agree with metas in which we only see 1 ADC per team (and, currently, ADCs that avoid building crit)?  Specifically, I think doubling AD isn't what matters, but doubling spell base damage is (which is why penetration builds are all the rage right now).
